content.description: The route at the entrance to the Grotto (gully 30m R of sixtoe crack)

This route follows a continious crack system for two good pitches up Six Toe Rock. Pro is good and widely available. Rock quality is excellent and the line is direct.

Pitch 1: 100' 5.8Start with a tricky move off the ground to get situated in the crack above. Follow the crack for 90 more feet to a bolt anchor.

Pitch 2: 95' 5.8+Continue up the crack until you reach a short section of offwidth (#4 camalot) just before the anchor.

Descent:2 Raps with a 60m rope from fixed anchors.

R of the Gulley with all those Ian Katz R routes..

Begin about 20' up left of a prominent, right-leaning, flared chimney. Jam a classic, right-leaning hand/fist crack, then ascend a short section of easy face climbing to the summit.

Takes " easy on " to the 3 old bolts, step left and gain the R trending crack system to end at the same abseil as sixtoes second pitch. There is a big tree growing out the crack at the top. Onsight 1st ascent. Best route in this area IMO!

Using stemming, jamming, or whatever else works, climb the severely flared, right-leaning chimney. When it peters out after 50', switch to jamming and continue up a fist crack that curves up left to a small flake/ledge. Face-climb to the top from here (run-out).

from half way up chocsuker, take a steep handcrack to a chain anchor (Fixe SS, 2x12mm x75mm Triplex). 2nd pitch is the meat, bust up the steep slab via some balancy moves on water runnels, to finish steeply via technical nibnobs
content.protection: bolted (10?x 3.5"x3/8 Fixe PS), To (2x1/2"x3.5") ps fixe rings. no extra gear needed for second pitch. From the top, a single 70m easily gets back to the belay. From here do a short abseil to the 1st chain on sixtoe as you wont be able to get back to the ground with one rope.

content.description: Not so easy and surprisingly awesome. 2 or 3 pitches. Climb crack farthest L of sixtoe 20m up the gulley, starting at a small rooflet. There are an optional set of loweroffs at just below halfway before the hard crack section. Finish the pitch at the tree with slings. One short pitch to the top.
content.protection: trad rack and number 4+5 camalot useful for the crux middle section.

content.description:
The obvious right-leaning crack that merges with Six Toe Crack at its midpoint. Originally done in 2 pitches. 1st pitch ended at the 3 dodgy old bolts and white tat, (death wish to use, just do it in one 60m pitch).

1 or 2 moves feel a bit airy, a bit above your gear...

and u get to do the cool OW bit on 6toe again!!
content.protection: Usual rack and No:4 for OW on sixtoe
content.location: Start 7m left of sixtoe in the wide crack/flake

content.description: an alternative 3rd pitch to Sixtoe crack. Step R from the belay and go up a thin seam past 5bolts

Dihedral just to right of 6 Toe Crack. Strenuous lie-backing is the character of the route.

Well protected, but fairly old school 5.9. Lots of moss/lichen at bottom of P1 makes me think it is not climbed very often, but I'm not a local, so who knows.

First 25' of P1 are probably the crux. Top of P1 is build your own anchor at approximately same vertical height as 6 Toe Crack. Then continue upwards...

At top of P2, we stepped left to share the 6 Toe Crack slung belay, then ran up the 3rd pitch of 6 Toe Crack to top out. Maybe better climbers would stay in the dihedral/lieback system...

Rappel down 6 Toe Crack with a single 60m rope for the descent.
content.protection: Standard rack. Mostly thin, but some larger pieces like #3 and #3.5 Camalot are handy
content.location: Obvious dihedral to right of 6 Toe Crack.
